title: Problem Overview
content: This header documents **Erdős Problem #228**, originally Littlewood's conjecture on flat polynomials. The question: do there exist polynomials P with ±1 coefficients such that |P(z)| ≈ √n for ALL |z|=1? Answer: YES (BBMST 2019).
mathContext: A 'flat' Littlewood polynomial has magnitude uniformly close to √n on the entire unit circle. This is remarkable because the constraint is global—not just on average, but pointwise everywhere.

title: Littlewood Polynomial
content: A **Littlewood polynomial** has all coefficients in {-1, +1}. These are polynomials P(z) = Σᵢ aᵢzⁱ where each aᵢ = ±1.
mathContext: IsLittlewoodPolynomial p := ∀ i ≤ p.natDegree, p.coeff i = 1 ∨ p.coeff i = -1. The binary constraint makes these polynomials special objects of study.

title: Flatness on Unit Circle
content: A polynomial is **flat** on the unit circle if |P(z)| stays between c₁√n and c₂√n for ALL |z|=1, where c₁, c₂ > 0 are constants independent of z and n.
mathContext: IsFlatOnUnitCircle p c₁ c₂ requires c₁ > 0 ∧ c₂ > 0 ∧ ∀ z with ‖z‖ = 1, c₁√n ≤ ‖p.eval z‖ ≤ c₂√n. This is a very strong uniform bound.

title: The Main Question
content: **Erdős Problem #228**: For all sufficiently large n, does there exist a flat Littlewood polynomial of degree n? This asks whether 'random' magnitude behavior can be achieved deterministically.
mathContext: Erdos228Question := ∃ c₁ c₂ > 0, ∀ᶠ n in atTop, ∃ p with degree n, IsLittlewoodPolynomial p ∧ IsFlatOnUnitCircle p c₁ c₂.

title: Why √n is Expected
content: **Intuition**: For a random Littlewood polynomial evaluated at z on the unit circle, |P(z)|² is a sum of n terms with random signs. By the central limit theorem, the magnitude behaves like √n.
mathContext: expected_magnitude_heuristic proves √n > 0 for n ≥ 1 using Real.sqrt_pos. This basic fact underlies the whole problem—we need a positive target magnitude.

title: The BBMST Theorem
content: **Theorem** (Balister-Bollobás-Morris-Sahasrabudhe-Tiba, 2019): Flat Littlewood polynomials exist. This resolved Littlewood's 50-year-old conjecture.
mathContext: axiom bbmst_theorem : Erdos228Question. The proof uses probabilistic construction with sophisticated derandomization, combining harmonic analysis and combinatorics.

title: The Answer
content: The answer to Erdős Problem #228 is **YES**: flat Littlewood polynomials exist for all n ≥ 2.
mathContext: theorem erdos_228_answer : Erdos228Question := bbmst_theorem. This directly invokes the axiomatized BBMST theorem.

title: Explicit Formulation
content: An equivalent explicit formulation: there exist universal constants c₁, c₂ > 0 and threshold N₀ such that for all n ≥ N₀, a flat degree-n Littlewood polynomial exists.
mathContext: This makes the constructive content clearer: we need specific numbers c₁, c₂, and N₀, not just abstract existence. The actual values from BBMST are not easily computable.

title: Hayman's Question
content: **Related Problem**: Does there exist c > 0 such that max_{|z|=1} |P(z)| > (1+c)√n for ALL Littlewood polynomials? This asks about lower bounds on the maximum.
mathContext: ErdosHaymanQuestion asks whether every Littlewood polynomial must have a 'spike' above (1+c)√n somewhere on the unit circle. This is distinct from flatness.

title: Summary
content: The summary combines our main results: the BBMST theorem holds (axiomatized), and √n > 0 for all n ≥ 1 (proved as the basic magnitude target).
mathContext: summary_erdos_228 : Erdos228Question ∧ (∀ n ≥ 1, √n > 0). The conjunction packages the key verified facts for export.
